introduction: While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:
text:
• In 1913, Emily Davison, a British suffragette, was struck by the King’s horse during the Epsom Derby.
• She walked onto the racetrack in a public protest for women’s voting rights.
• Her injuries were fatal, and her action sparked nationwide debate.
• Many regarded her as a martyr for the women’s suffrage cause.
• British women over 30 gained the vote in 1918; full suffrage was granted in 1928.
question: The student wants to emphasize the dramatic impact of Emily Davison’s protest on public discourse. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?
A: Emily Davison was a British suffragette who walked onto the track at the Epsom Derby in 1913.
B: After the incident, many regarded Davison as a martyr, fueling nationwide debate on the women’s suffrage cause.
C: Women over 30 in Britain gained the vote in 1918, with full suffrage following later in 1928.
D: King George V was reportedly watching the race when Davison entered the track.
explanation: Choice B highlights the immediate response—Davison was seen as a martyr—which ignited widespread debate, illustrating the protest’s dramatic effect on public discourse.
